results.title: ‘Pam & Tommy’: A Story of Sex, Crimes and Videotape
results.abstract: A new Hulu series starring Lily James and Sebastian Stan is a picaresque romp through the history of the stolen sex tape that changed pop culture.

multimedia.caption: “Lily and I didn’t really see each other outside of those costumes until the end,” Sebastian Stan said of playing Tommy Lee, with Lily James as Pamela Anderson. “Even now, we see each other for press, and we’re like, ‘This is your hair?’”
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

results.title: New Life for the Wyeth Legacy Five Miles Out to Sea
results.abstract: Colby College has acquired two islands off Maine that inspired the first family of American art, and will show newly discovered works that Andrew Wyeth drew in secret.

multimedia.caption: The painter Jamie Wyeth and his dog Iggy on the dock at Benner Island, which his mother, Betsy Wyeth, purchased in 1990. Benner and the neighboring Allen Island have been acquired by Colby College.
multimedia.copyright: Cig Harvey for The New York Times

results.title: Spotify Defends Handling of Joe Rogan Controversy Amid Uproar
results.abstract: The company released earnings figures a week after Neil Young and others pulled their music to protest what they called vaccine misinformation on Rogan’s podcast.

multimedia.caption: Daniel Ek, Spotify’s chief executive and co-founder, in 2015.

results.title: Yale to Evaluate Policies on Donor Gifts and Influence
results.abstract: Plans for a new faculty committee to protect academic freedom came after the head of a prestigious program resigned, citing donor interference.

multimedia.caption: Beverly Gage, a professor of history at Yale, resigned last year because she felt the administration had failed to defend against what she saw as interference in the curriculum by prominent and deep-pocketed donors.
multimedia.copyright: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times

results.title: Who Will Be Nominated for the Oscars? Here Are Our Projections.
results.abstract: The list will be unveiled Feb. 8. Our expert’s predictions are based on precursor awards and industry scuttlebutt. But in an unusually open year, he’d love to be wrong.

multimedia.caption: Unlike previous years, no other awards will have been handed out before the Oscar nominations are unveiled next week.

results.title: How Hugh Jackman, Sutton Foster and ‘The Music Man’ Withstood Covid
results.abstract: Nearly 60 cast and crew members have tested positive since rehearsals began. Now, following a 10-day shutdown during previews, opening night is near.

multimedia.caption: “Even though we lost 10 days, we’re still in good shape,” said Sutton Foster, above, with Hugh Jackman.
multimedia.copyright: Landon Nordeman for The New York Times

results.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Music for Dance
results.abstract: Reggae, house, step, ballet, tap, jazz: Listen to the sounds that have inspired great choreographers.

results.title: Sara Ramirez Is Not Che Diaz
results.abstract: Ramirez doesn’t really relate to Che, the most polarizing character in “And Just Like That.” But the actor is “really proud of the representation that we’ve created.”

multimedia.caption: Che Diaz, Sara Ramirez’s character in the “Sex and the City” sequel series, has been divisive. The season finale debuts on Thursday.

results.title: It’s Gold, Baby. But Niclas Castello’s Cube Is Nothing New in Art.
results.abstract: The artist’s solid gold cube, which appeared for one day in Central Park, was Instagram bait, an NFT promotion and even kind of pretty.
results.byline: By Will Heinrich and Sam Youkilis

results.title: Clad in a Kimono, a Painter of Warriors Returns to Downtown New York
results.abstract: Chaz Guest, a favorite of Oprah, the Obamas and Angelina Jolie, has a gallery show featuring the actor Michael K. Williams, who modeled just before he died.

multimedia.caption: Chaz Guest, artist and Japanophile, at the Vito Schnabel Gallery on Clarkson Street in Manhattan. Based in Los Angeles, he is a former New Yorker who taught himself to paint just a few blocks away.
multimedia.copyright: Kendall Bessent for The New York Times

results.title: A Venice Biennale Informed by the Pandemic Will Spotlight Women
results.abstract: For the 59th edition of the longest-running survey of contemporary art, Cecilia Alemani selected mostly female artists, many of color, from around the world.

multimedia.caption: Image from a new video by Lynn Hershman Leeson, “Logic Paralyzes the Heart” (2021). The work will be featured in the Venice Biennale this spring.
multimedia.copyright: Lynn Hershman Leeson/Altman Siegel, San Francisco and Bridget Donahue, New York

results.title: Dolly Parton, Eminem and A Tribe Called Quest Are Rock Hall Nominees
results.abstract: This year’s slate of 17 acts eligible for induction span rap, country, folk, pop and more.
org_facet: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum

multimedia.caption: Dolly Parton appears on the ballot for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame for the first time this year.

results.title: A Music Museum Opens in the Heart of Hungary’s Culture Wars
results.abstract: At City Park in Budapest, a building project has come to exemplify the politics of Viktor Orban, the country’s far-right prime minister.
org_facet: House of Music, Hungary (Budapest, Hungary, Museum)

multimedia.caption: The House of Music, Hungary, designed by the Japanese architect Sou Fujimoto, opened in Budapest last month.
multimedia.copyright: Akos Stiller for The New York Times

results.title: Review: In ‘MJ,’ No One’s Looking at the Man in the Mirror
results.abstract: A new jukebox musical tells the story of Michael Jackson. Except for the big story.

multimedia.caption: Myles Frost as Michael Jackson in the new musical “MJ” at the Neil Simon Theater.

results.title: On English Stages, Tales From the Asylum
results.abstract: Two new plays offer very different experiences of the sanitarium, one starring Mark Rylance and the other spotlighting a fast-rising actress.

multimedia.caption: Mark Rylance, center, as the title character, a 19th-century physician, in “Dr. Semmelweis” at the Bristol Old Vic.

results.title: Late Night Comments on the Washington Commanders
results.abstract: The hosts didn’t think much of the N.F.L. team’s long-awaited new name. Jimmy Kimmel pointed out that it’s also the name of the president’s dog.
des_facet: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “‘The Commanders’ kind of sounds like an action movie where Dolph Lungren and Sylvester Stallone join forces to defend their assisted living facility,” Jimmy Kimmel said on Wednesday.

results.title: Lawsuit Against Live Nation Details the Killing of Drakeo the Ruler
results.abstract: The Los Angeles rapper’s family is suing the promoters of the Once Upon a Time in LA festival, citing negligence in the face of a large gang presence.

multimedia.caption: Drakeo the Ruler was fatally stabbed on Dec. 18 in Los Angeles at the Once Upon a Time in LA festival.
multimedia.copyright: Wyatt Winfrey/Scott Jawson, via Associated Press

results.title: Birju Maharaj, Virtuoso of Classical Indian Dance, Dies at 83
results.abstract: Mr. Maharaj choreographed for Bollywood, but was chiefly known for carrying the torch of Kathak, one of India’s major dance traditions.

multimedia.caption: Birju Maharaj at the Peter Norton Symphony Space in Manhattan in 2012. He was a master of the ancient Indian dance tradition known as Kathak.
multimedia.copyright: Julieta Cervantes for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Lost City’ and a Richard Linklater Film Will Play SXSW
results.abstract: The film festival will return to primarily in-person screenings in Austin, Texas, with some online options.
des_facet: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference
The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent (Movie)

multimedia.caption: From left, Brad Pitt, Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum in “The Lost City.”

results.title: The Name of This Interviewee Is David Byrne
results.abstract: In advance of a show of his drawings at New York’s Pace Gallery, the polymathic performer answered T’s Artist’s Questionnaire.

multimedia.caption: The artist and performer David Byrne in his SoHo office.

results.title: He Suffered Under Romania’s Dictatorship. Then He Was Forced to Spy for It.
results.abstract: Ruta Sepetys’s latest historical Y.A. novel, “I Must Betray You,” follows the life of a teenager who is blackmailed to become an informer for a repressive Communist regime.

results.title: Danai Gurira Will Star as Richard III at Shakespeare in the Park
results.abstract: The actress, known for “The Walking Dead” and “Black Panther,” will headline a return to semi-normal for the annual festival, which will also present “As You Like It.”

multimedia.caption: Danai Gurira in 2020. She also starred in Shakespeare in the Park’s 2011 production of “Measure for Measure.”

results.title: Jacob’s Pillow Announces Lineup for 2022 Season
results.abstract: The influential dance festival is returning to its indoor theater after the pandemic complicated the last two seasons.

multimedia.caption: Ronald K. Brown’s company Evidence in “The Equality of Night and Day,” which is to have its premiere at Jacob’s Pillow.

results.title: Ashley Flowers Wants to Up the Ante of True Crime
results.abstract: The “Crime Junkie” co-host, who oversees a network of popular podcasts, has a new podcast aimed at heating up the “coldest of cases.”

multimedia.caption: Ashley Flowers “is giving people what they want, not what the cultural elite tells them they should want,” one podcaster said.

results.title: Watch These 11 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
results.abstract: February’s exodus includes two best picture winners and a lot more. Catch these while you can.

multimedia.caption: Arnold Schwarzenegger in a scene from “Terminator 2: Judgment Day.”

results.title: Monica Vitti, ‘Queen of Italian Cinema,’ Dies at 90
results.abstract: Both sensual and cerebral, she made her mark on the international scene in the 1960s, when visionary directors like Michelangelo Antonioni were remaking the cinema landscape.

multimedia.caption: Monica Vitti, center, in a scene from Michelangelo Antonioni’s 1960 movie, “L’Avventura.” Antonioni was her companion for a decade, and she was his muse and alter ego.

results.title: ‘Last Looks’ Review: A Hollywood Murder Mystery Full of Clichés
results.abstract: A former police officer is drawn back into duty in a case involving a drunken TV star, played by Mel Gibson, and the plot thickens.

multimedia.caption: Charlie Hunnam, left, and Mel Gibson in “Last Looks,” directed by Tim Kirkby.

results.title: ‘Vladimir,’ a Debut That Celebrates Transgression — Up to a Point
results.abstract: In Julia May Jonas’s first novel, a married literature professor becomes obsessed with a younger experimental writer.

results.title: Savior? Monster? A Messianic Leader Rallies His Followers.
results.abstract: The Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk‘s novel “The Books of Jacob” is based on the life of the self-proclaimed messiah Jacob Frank.

multimedia.caption: Olga Tokarczuk

results.title: Late Night Talks Tom Brady’s Retirement
results.abstract: “You know you’ve been around a long time when you debuted the same year as ‘The Thong Song,’” Jimmy Fallon joked on Tuesday.
des_facet: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Jimmy Fallon said that Tom Brady is “basically the N.F.L.’s Meryl Streep.”

results.title: Review: In ‘Prayer for the French Republic,’ Echoes of the Past
results.abstract: Joshua Harmon’s ambitious new play toggles between a contemporary Jewish family facing growing antisemitism and their relatives during World War II.

multimedia.caption: From left: Yair Ben-Dor, Molly Ranson and Francis Benhamou in “Prayer for the French Republic.”

results.title: Donald Mahler, Prolific Ballet Choreographer, Dies at 88
results.abstract: After dancing with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet and other companies, he became its director. He was also well known for his staging of works by Antony Tudor.

multimedia.caption: The choreographer Donald Mahler in 2010 during rehearsals for a production of Antony Tudor’s “Echoing of Trumpets” at the Colorado Ballet. Mr. Mahler was known internationally for his stagings of Mr. Tudor’s work.
multimedia.copyright: Andy Cross/The Denver Post via Getty Images

results.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in February
results.abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of February’s most promising new titles.

multimedia.caption: Olly Sholotan, left, as Carlton Banks and Jabari Banks as Will Smith in “Bel-Air.”

results.title: On ‘The 7th Hand,’ Immanuel Wilkins Sees Jazz as an Escape Pod
results.abstract: The alto saxophonist’s second album is blues-based, gospel-infused, intellectually considered music that secures his quartet’s commanding status on the scene.

multimedia.caption: The 24-year-old saxophonist Immanuel Wilkins has released his second album on Blue Note Records.

results.title: These Talkies Star Complicated Women You Might Well Recognize
results.abstract: A MoMA series puts the spotlight on a Hollywood era when actresses broke free of stereotypes that would later dominate movies for decades.
des_facet: The Bitter Tea of General Yen (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Clara Bow in “The Wild Party” (1929), directed by Dorothy Arzner, part of the series “Dames, Janes, Dolls and Canaries.”
multimedia.copyright: via The Museum of Modern Art Film Stills Archive

results.title: Calling All Tap Dance Kids (It’s Not the Acting Kid or the Singing Kid)
results.abstract: The challenge of casting the Encores! revival of “The Tap Dance Kid” exposes some of the complications of tap, show business and Black history.

multimedia.caption: Foreground, the choreographer Jared Grimes, left, and the director Kenny Leon watch DeWitt Fleming and Alexander Bello, 13, rehearse.
multimedia.copyright: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times

results.title: Remembering Greg Tate, Critic and Catalyst
results.abstract: Conversations with two of his contemporaries about the fertile scenes he covered, and the indelible impression he left.
des_facet: Flyboy in the Buttermilk: Essays on Contemporary America (Book)

multimedia.copyright: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times

results.title: J Dilla Was a Revered Rap Producer. A New Book Deepens His Legacy.
results.abstract: The Detroit musician wasn’t known to give many interviews, and his influence has grown exponentially since his 2006 death. “Dilla Time” by Dan Charnas explores what drove him.

multimedia.caption: The musician J Dilla died in 2006 at 32. A new book from Dan Charnas explored his influence, which went beyond hip-hop and soul and extended to pop, electronic music and jazz.

results.title: Behind Neil Young vs. Spotify, a Fraught Relationship With Musicians
results.abstract: The rocker touched off a debate about free speech and the responsibility of tech platforms. How many artists will follow him, now that streaming dominates the business?

multimedia.caption: Neil Young asked Spotify to choose between him and its star podcaster, Joe Rogan. He ended up removing his music from the streaming service.
